text.0: There has been promising #COVID19 vaccine results and progress on #HIV prevention — all in one great day. @PaulSaxMD discusses the latest news in HIV and ID Observations. https://t.co/VJOjKnfbjI https://t.co/G68GLFIni9
text.1: The FDA has issued an emergency use authorization for balmanivimab, a monoclonal antibody, for mild-to-moderate #COVID19. Elsewhere, a study finds that reducing maximum occupancy at certain public venues will do more to limit transmission than reducing mobility overall.
text.2: This letter describes an immunocompromised patient who had persistent infection with #SARSCoV2 over a period of months, despite several courses of remdesivir. Phylogenetic analysis showed accelerated viral evolution. #COVID19
text.3: Select Villages in Niger offered azithromycin or placebo to children 1 to 59 months of age every 6 months to 4 years. Stool samples collected showed the antibiotic was more common among children living in villages that received azithromycin over those who received placebo.
text.4: This post marketing surveillance study of intussusception risk among infants in India who received the Indian-made oral rotavirus vaccine (Rotavac) did not show an increased risk of intussusception in any risk window.
text.5: Holly Taylor discusses the ethical issues involved in conducting Covid-19 vaccine research in correctional facilities. #COVID19 #SARSCoV2
text.6: In this audio interview conducted on November 9, the editors are joined by Dr. Janet Woodcock of Operation Warp Speed to discuss the pace of discovery in the U.S. response to #COVID19. #SARSCoV2
